text: Boonstra D, Joseph E. Cavanaugh (2024). satpt: Saturation Point Analysis Sample Proportions. R package version 0.0.0.9000, https://deboonstra.github.io/satpt/.
code: @Manual{,   title = {satpt: Saturation Point Analysis for Sample Proportions},   author = {D. Erik Boonstra and {Joseph E. Cavanaugh}},   year = {2024},   note = {R package version 0.0.0.9000},   url = {https://deboonstra.github.io/satpt/}, }

what: Saturation Point Analysis for Sample Proportions
title: Saturation Point Analysis for Sample Proportions
text: goal satpt R package identify saturation point multinomial responses survey using standard errors sample proportions

title: Saturation Point Analysis for Sample Proportions
text: can install development version satpt

title: Saturation Point Analysis for Sample Proportions
text: basic usage satpt simply specify responses survey y data collection period information , seen .
code: data(ein) satpt::satpt(y = ein$q2, by = ein$wave) Saturation achieved?  Yes  Overall Sample Proportions and Standard Errors ==============================================             y Statistics   Not at all   Once Rarely Sometimes  Often   Proportion     0.2531 0.0375 0.3688    0.2656 0.0750   SE             0.0172 0.0075 0.0191    0.0175 0.0104

title: Saturation Point Analysis for Sample Proportions
text: specification dimension names contigency table, sample proportions, standard error wanted, use one two methods.

title: Saturation Point Analysis for Sample Proportions
code: res <- satpt::satpt(   y = ein$q2,   by = ein$wave,   dimnames = c("Responses to survey", "Collection period") ) res$counts # accessing contingency table Responses to survey Collection period Not at all Once Rarely Sometimes Often                 1         85   15    109        88    27                 2         37    5     59        34    11                 3         40    4     68        48    10

title: Saturation Point Analysis for Sample Proportions
code: res <- satpt::satpt(   y = ein$q2,   by = ein$wave,   dimnames = c("by" = "Collection period", "y" = "Responses to survey") ) res$phat # accessing sample proportions table Responses to survey Collection period Not at all       Once    Rarely Sometimes      Often                 1  0.2623457 0.04629630 0.3364198 0.2716049 0.08333333                 2  0.2534247 0.03424658 0.4041096 0.2328767 0.07534247                 3  0.2352941 0.02352941 0.4000000 0.2823529 0.05882353

what: Emerging Infectious Network (EIN) survey data — ein
title: Emerging Infectious Network (EIN) survey data — ein
text: Responses survey questions advanced molecular diagnostic testing infectious diseases presented medical personnel members EIN.

title: Emerging Infectious Network (EIN) survey data — ein
Emerging Infectious Network (EIN) survey data — ein
text: data.frame 643 observations 3 variables. wave data collect period responses collected . q1 responses types advanced molecular diagnostic tests ordered used. example responses based select apply data collection process. Possible values Broad range 16S rRNA gene sequencing (Broadrange), Whole genome sequencing (Wholegenome), Metagenomic next-generation sequencing (MNGS), None (None), (), data values listed within parentheses. multiple responses present data values separated "|". q2 responses often within past two years advanced molecular diagnostic testing performed. Possible values , , Rarely (quarterly less often), Sometimes (monthly), Often (weekly). example responses collected come multinomial distribution.

title: Emerging Infectious Network (EIN) survey data — ein
text: Difficult Diagnoses

what: Automatic placement of legends for plots — legend_top
title: Automatic placement of legends for plots — legend_top
text: Produce legend either right plot window.

title: Automatic placement of legends for plots — legend_top
Automatic placement of legends for plots — legend_top
text: horiz logical; TRUE, set legend horizontally rather vertically (specifying horiz overrides ncol specification) ... arguments passed graphics::legend()

title: Automatic placement of legends for plots — legend_top
code: # loading data data(ein)  # performing saturation point analysis fit <- satpt::satpt(   y = ein$q2,   by = ein$wave,   dimnames = c("Response collected", "Collection period") )  # plotting standard errors graphics::par(oma = c(0, 0, 0, 8)) plot(fit, threshold = TRUE)  # adding legend legend_right(   legend = "Saturation\nthreshold",   col = "firebrick", lty = 3, lwd = 2,   cex = 0.75 )

what: Plot of saturation point analysis — plot.satpt
title: Plot of saturation point analysis — plot.satpt
text: Plotting overall standard errors calculated saturation point anlaysis performed satpt().

title: Plot of saturation point analysis — plot.satpt
code: # S3 method for class 'satpt' plot(x, threshold = TRUE, ...)

title: Plot of saturation point analysis — plot.satpt
text: x satpt object plotted. threshold logical; TRUE, display saturation threshold. Default TRUE. ... arguments passed graphics::barplot()

title: Plot of saturation point analysis — plot.satpt
code: # loading data data(ein)  # performing saturation point analysis fit1 <- satpt::satpt(y = ein$q2) fit2 <- satpt::satpt(   y = ein$q2,   by = ein$wave,   dimnames = c("Response collected", "Collection period") )  # plotting standard errors plot(fit1)  plot(fit2)

title: Print saturation point analysis — print.satpt
text: print prints satpt objects created satpt().

title: Print saturation point analysis — print.satpt
code: # S3 method for class 'satpt' print(x, digits = max(3, getOption("digits") - 3), ...)

title: Print saturation point analysis — print.satpt
text: x satpt object printed. digits Minimal number significant digits. Default max(3, getOption("digits") - 3). ... Arguments passed base::print

title: Saturation point analysis — satpt
text: Saturation point analysis multinomial responses survey using standard errors sample proportions responses.

title: Saturation point analysis — satpt
code: satpt(   y,   by = NULL,   exclude = c(NA, NaN),   alpha = 0.05,   threshold = 0.05,   dimnames = NULL )

title: Saturation point analysis — satpt
text: y Vector values determine saturation achieved. Vector values indicate y collected. Default NULL. exclude Vector values excluded y . Generally, used denote missing values. Default NA NaN. alpha Significance level Pearson's \(\chi^2\) test independence. Default 0.05. threshold Saturation threshold applied standard errors sample proportions. Default 0.05. dimnames Character vector names y displaying contingency table, sample proportions, standard error matrices. dimnames unnamed vector first entry name y variable second entry name variable. dimnames named vector, order values matter, long elements named "y" "". Default NULL.

title: Saturation point analysis — satpt
text: object S3 class "satpt" containing saturation logical value indicating whether response categories achieved saturation given defined threshold. value TRUE indicates saturation achieved value FALSE indicates saturation achieved data needed achieve saturation. counts matrix containing observed cell counts contigency table created y provided. phat matrix containing row-wise sample proportions observed contigency table (counts). se matrix containing standard errors calculated sample proportions (phat). test htest object produced stats::chisq.test() containing results \(\chi^2\) test independence. N Total number observations response provided. total data.frame 5 variables describing overall collected sample. categories variable provides unique categories listed y. counts, phat, se provide overall cell counts, sample proportions, standard errors categories, respectively. standard errors reported overall sample proportions calculated based presence response bias, detailed . Finally, saturation variable logical variable denoting whether saturation achieved individual category given saturation threshold defined. hindex Heterogeneity index sample proportions calculated mean absolute deviation.

title: Saturation point analysis — satpt
text: argument specified responses collected y -product data collection mechanism defined variable. priori data collection mechanism defined, argument defined. Generally, data collected randomly collected first data collection period, "priori data collection mechanism." Functionality satpt() depends limited use stats::ftable(). specifically, y, , exclude directly used stats::ftable() create contingency table collected data. contingency table created stats::ftable() converted matrix easier use functions. dimnames argument used, manipulates attributes created ftable, impacts dimension names resulting matrix. Specification argument automatically calls Pearson's \(\chi^2\) test independence heterogeneity index sample proportions calculated. \(\chi^2\) test independence conducted determine response bias present within responses y due data collection periods (). response bias present pooled standard errors overall sample proportions response category reported, pooled standard errors account response bias. heterogeneity index defined mean absoluted difference sample proportions response category within data collection period () relative overall sample proportions response category. index reflects average deviation data collection period proportions overall sample proportions. Smaller values indicate sample proportions data collection periods less dissimilar. measure importance response bias present. specified test independence conducted heterogeneity index calculated. satpt assumes response possible specified. Thus, need check response bias specified.

title: Saturation point analysis — satpt
text: returned satpt object contain NULL values test hindex specified. done satpt assumes specified data collected intervals.

title: Saturation point analysis — satpt
code: data(ein)  # Assuming response bias is not a possiblity satpt::satpt(y = ein$q2) #> Saturation achieved?  Yes  #> Overall Sample Proportions and Standard Errors #> ============================================== #>             y #> Statistics   Not at all   Once Rarely Sometimes  Often #>   Proportion     0.2531 0.0375 0.3688    0.2656 0.0750 #>   SE             0.0172 0.0075 0.0191    0.0175 0.0104  # Examining saturation given data collected at different times and # response bias is possible. satpt::satpt(y = ein$q2, by = ein$wave) #> Saturation achieved?  Yes  #> Overall Sample Proportions and Standard Errors #> ============================================== #>             y #> Statistics   Not at all   Once Rarely Sometimes  Often #>   Proportion     0.2531 0.0375 0.3688    0.2656 0.0750 #>   SE             0.0172 0.0075 0.0191    0.0175 0.0104

title: Simulation of multinomial responses — simulate
text: Simulating data multinomial responses collected survey.

title: Simulation of multinomial responses — simulate
text: n Integer specifying number random samples draw. size Vector integer values, say \(N_i\), specifying sample sizes \(= 1, \ldots , \) data collection periods. prob Numeric non-negative vector matrix specifying probabilities K response categories \(\) data collection periods. categories Vector values specifying K category labels represented. Default NULL.

title: Simulation of multinomial responses — simulate
text: data.frame \(N = \sum_{}N_{}\) rows n + 1 variables, described . period Data collection period defined length size responses1 ... n Simulated multinomial responses either values defined categories Category k,  \(k = 1, \ldots , K\)

title: Simulation of multinomial responses — simulate
text: Running backend stats::rmultinom(). , see documentation stats::rmultinom()information multinomial responses generated. arguments size prob directly connect comes generating multinomial responses multiple data collection periods. prob may either vector matrix specifying probabilities K response categories. size specified generate data multiple data collection periods, prob must specified numeric vector length length(size) times K numeric matrix length(size) rows K columns, row matrix specify K probabilities data collection period. categories defined (categories = NULL) simulate create default lables Category k,  \(k = 1, \ldots , K\).

title: Simulation of multinomial responses — simulate
code: # Creating 10 simulated data sets of with a sample size of 100, where there # are two possible response categories with a 50% chance of being selected. simulate(n = 10, size = 100, prob = c(0.5, title: Saturation point analysis summary — summary.satpt
text: summary summarizes saturation point analysis performed satpt(). print prints summary saturation point analysis produced summary.satpt().

title: Saturation point analysis summary — summary.satpt
code: # S3 method for class 'satpt' summary(object, digits = max(3, getOption("digits") - 3), ...)  # S3 method for class 'summary.satpt' print(x, ...)

title: Saturation point analysis summary — summary.satpt
